{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3491617,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T15:22:44.065Z","cooked":"

A relatively new concept in the minds of those who have done swerve before is the constant in CTRE’s swerve implementation called kCoupleRatio

Code Snippet from SwerveWithChoreo example project

// Every 1 rotation of the azimuth results in kCoupleRatio drive motor turns;
// This may need to be tuned to your individual robot
private static final double kCoupleRatio = 3.8181818181818183;

I’m 100% positive this is a dummy number in their example of course. My questions/thoughts are do we even really need this if the drive wheel is set to brake mode. If we do how should one go about determining it. Trial/Error. Simple experiment with logging. ??

The coupling ratio is how much your drive motor moves when the module spins 360. This number provides an improvement during match. It is not required though.

{Incorrect}
Depending on what gearing your module has (I am assuming you are using SDS) the coupling ratio is the drive gear ratio

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T15:50:29.517Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":285,"readers_count":284,"score":72.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483380,"topic_slug":"kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve","display_username":"Natalie Daleo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":3,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48345,"username":"narmstro","name":"Nicholas Armstrong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63494,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"5431 Programming Lead"},"post_url":"/t/kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve/483380/4","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491636,"name":"","username":"nstrike","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nstrike/{size}/167038_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T15:41:43.863Z","cooked":"

I think you are confusing the drive gear ratio with the coupling ratio. These are 2 very separate things.

The coupling ratio can be measured by dx/dy of the drive wheel movement over the number of complete rotations done on the azimuth motor.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T15:41:43.863Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":278,"readers_count":277,"score":85.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483380,"topic_slug":"kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":63494,"username":"Natalie5431","name":"Natalie Daleo","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/91b2a8/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":51887,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"YAGSL Creator & Maintainer"},"post_url":"/t/kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve/483380/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491738,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T17:40:52.278Z","cooked":"

Coupling ratio is explained a bit here in our documentation: Swerve Builder API.

narmstro:

I’m 100% positive this is a dummy number in their example of course.

If the coupling ratio in the generated TunerConstants is non-zero, then it should already be correct, as it is generated for COTS modules based on the first stage of the drive gear ratio (the inverse of which is the coupling ratio for all current COTS modules). You can use the test procedure in our documentation to verify the ratio.

For the coupling ratio. Why lock the wheel in place and observe the drive motor rotations while rotating the steer. Won’t it be zero if I lock it in place

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T17:50:25.619Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":253,"readers_count":252,"score":60.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":483380,"topic_slug":"kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve/483380/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491759,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T17:53:45.991Z","cooked":"

No, that’s what the coupling ratio represents. As the azimuth rotates, the drive motor (and/or the wheel) spins a bit as well because of mechanical coupling between the two. Locking the wheel in place lets all that coupled motion go to the drive motor, which is easier to observe numerically. You could also lock the drive motor in place, in which case you will see the wheel look like it’s driving as you spin the azimuth (often around 0.6 wheel rotations per azimuth rotation).

Note that our coupling ratio is drive motor rotor rotations to steer rotations, not wheel rotations to steer rotations.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T17:56:13.603Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":245,"readers_count":244,"score":59.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":483380,"topic_slug":"kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve","display_username":"Benjamin Hall","primary_group_name":"CTRE","flair_name":"CTRE","flair_url":"/uploads/default/original/3X/1/b/1bd2b430e1bb6427d1c6504ff6abcd31de851a6d.png","flair_bg_color":"","flair_color":"","flair_group_id":57,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":48345,"username":"narmstro","name":"Nicholas Armstrong","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48146,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Software Engineering Intern at CTR Electronics"},"post_url":"/t/kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve/483380/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491784,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T18:16:09.164Z","cooked":"

Okay. It says on the website wheel not drive motor.

In the first paragraph

I’m curious how much difference this makes.

If you drive a one-meter circle, how much does the coupling factor change the odometry? The circumference would be ~3.14 meters, the azimuth will have turned once, so the ratio says the drive motor will turn 3.8 times, which means the wheel turns 0.6 times at L3, so about 0.2 meters of difference, or 6%.

This is a larger error than we see in odometry from moderate-speed straight-line carpet interaction, so fixing it seems like a good idea?

Do I have that math right?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T18:28:34.378Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":221,"readers_count":220,"score":54.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":483380,"topic_slug":"kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve/483380/11","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491821,"name":"Nicholas Armstrong","username":"narmstro","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/5e9695/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T18:43:39.213Z","cooked":"

What modules were used for the example code

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T18:43:39.213Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":217,"readers_count":216,"score":53.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483380,"topic_slug":"kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":48146,"username":"bhall-ctre","name":"Benjamin Hall","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve/483380/12","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491883,"name":"","username":"AvocadoPeel","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/avocadopeel/{size}/232401_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T20:02:43.490Z","cooked":"

from my testing it seems insignificant for odometry over the course of a full path, as the aimuth turns the different directions of odometry all cancel each other out mostly, i think.

mostly helps with reducing the slight “wiggle” the swerve has with the modules snapping while moving slowly

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-01-24T20:02:43.490Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":209,"readers_count":208,"score":41.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":483380,"topic_slug":"kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":53190,"username":"truher","name":"joel truher","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/truher/{size}/172222_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":61239,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve/483380/13","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3491917,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-24T20:41:31.646Z","cooked":"

Because the error in odometry is spread out throughout the entire circular motion, the actual final error in your robot pose is going to be less than 0.2 m. From a bit of testing we’ve done, a pretty typical 30-second maneuver can result in about 0.1 m of error in the final pose. It’s small enough that vision integration easily corrects for it. But 0.1 m is still pretty significant, so we account for it anyways because it’s easy to do so (and not everyone uses vision).

narmstro:

What modules were used for the example code

I believe our SwerveWithPathPlanner example uses the WCP Legacy Swerve X flipped gear modules with the 7.36 drive ratio. You should use the Tuner X Swerve Project Generator to create a TunerConstants file for your specific robot.

We have. There was something in the documentation about the coupling ratio being the inverse of the first stage gear?

Did I misread that or is that a (perhaps) simpler way to get started on the coupling ratio

If you’ve already generated your TunerConstants and the generated coupling ratio is non-zero, there is nothing more you need to do. If you want, you can manually verify that the coupling ratio is correct following the test procedure in our documentation (locking the wheel in place, rotating the azimuth a few times, and looking at the change in the drive motor position).

So we generated the TunerConstants and got zero.

So the first stage of our drive wheel gear box is a 12 tooth gear to 50 tooth gear so could our coupling ratio be 50 / 12?

Did you select custom as your module manufacturer? We only prefill it if it’s one of the built-in options.

I did. I assume that was why I got 0.0.

Though I looked up our drive wheel gearing. Pinion gear has 12 teeth. The gear it connects to is 50 teeth. So the inverse of the first stage would be 50 : 12 right?

FYI: We are using the new Thrifty Swerve 2.0

","post_number":19,"post_type":1,"posts_count":45,"updated_at":"2025-01-26T16:03:44.456Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":18,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":162,"readers_count":161,"score":47.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":483380,"topic_slug":"kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve","display_username":"Nicholas Armstrong","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.thethriftybot.com/products/thrifty-swerve","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Thrifty Swerve","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":61981,"username":"daltzsmith","name":"Dalton","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/daltzsmith/{size}/206287_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":48345,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/kcoupleratio-in-ctre-swerve/483380/19","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3493302,"name":"Benjamin Hall","username":"bhall-ctre","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bhall-ctre/{size}/198180_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-26T22:51:02.043Z","cooked":"

In all likelihood, then yes, I would expect 50.0/12.0 (4.16666667) to be your coupling ratio. I would perform the experiment in our documentation to verify it, though, as the coupling ratio being the inverse of the first drive stage has only been validated with the COTS modules that are supported in Tuner X.
